1.text:
>> DAVID NASSER: Uh, real quick let me introduce
to you our other honored guest today. Obviously

6.text:
you know, you've marked it on your calendar,
and um, we're all just very excited to have

11.text:
Duck Dynasty's own, the Robertsons here with
us today! Honored, excited. Let me just, let

20.text:
me just say that this is a - this a homecoming
for them. This is family weekend for them!

26.text:
They're not just coming to speak, honestly,
they're coming to - to pour into us, but they're

31.text:
also coming to see family. ‘Cause you guys
know right? That um, that John Luke and his

36.text:
wife are just walking around as freshman around
here - I've seen all the selfies. You've got

41.text:
about another three days before that's got
to stop. Leave these people alone, all right?

45.text:
So, um, they're amazing people - they've been
patient with you, but uh, just know that they

50.text:
- they've come here not to be celebrities,
but they've come here just to be servants,

53.text:
and to be students, and to learn, but it's
just great to have them in the house. You

57.text:
know, right, you know that in this particular
moment, God has favored greatly this family,

64.text:
and God has elevated them, not for their stock;
God has elevated them so that men can see

69.text:
them, and them as ambassadors for Christ,
that they can then really just minister to

75.text:
the country. And this little show, this little
A&E reality show started out as you know,

81.text:
faith, family, and facial hair. You know,
and then it's evolved... that's what Barbara

87.text:
Walters said about them, but then they evolved
from that and it literally became this generation's

93.text:
Leave it to Beaver, of one sense. This has
become this generation's you know, just like

98.text:
the Andy Griffith Show. It really has become
the show that the world watches. It's become

104.text:
the show that's family friendly, and mom and
dad know they can turn the TV on and, and

109.text:
they're not going to have to have their kids
like, tucked in later on that night, shaking

113.text:
because they're having to explain to a nine
year old something that shouldn't be explained

116.text:
- it's just great to see this family honor
the Lord.

119.text:
Uh, one of the things that I love about the
show - I don't know you - what your favorite

123.text:
thing is - I love a lot of things, but one
of my favorite things about this show is how

126.text:
they always end back at the table, and they
always stand back in prayer in submission,

132.text:
and um, and then they've just been an incredible
witness, I just think about all the people

137.text:
who have witnessed, who've never come to a
church, who would never at this moment in

142.text:
their life come to a Christian concert. They'd
never enroll at Liberty University, but they

146.text:
turn on their TV and they witnessed, and they've
seen the gospel shared through just um, the

153.text:
testimony of this family. And so we have the
honor of interviewing just, um two of the

158.text:
ladies of the Duck Commander Dynasty, all
right? And so, can we just right off the bat

164.text:
just put our hands together for Sadie Robertson,
everybody! Have a seat. Sadie we're just so

179.text:
>> SADIE ROBERTSON: Thanks! I'm so happy to
be here! Good morning everybody!

183.text:
>> NASSER: A lot of fans. A lot, a lot of
fans. Obviously, uh, you know you just turned

189.text:
18, but happy birthday by the way! That's
amazing. But, so when you look at your resume

197.text:
as an 18-year-old, I mean are you kidding
me? You've got a clothing line, you just started

202.text:
a movement that we'll talk about here in just
a minute, you're on one of the largest, largest

209.text:
platforms in the world through Duck Dynasty.
You just continue, just you're an author,

214.text:
you're a blogger, you're just everywhere,
doing all kinds of incredible things. So that's

218.text:
all before high school. So, I guess our big,
first question is, um, after you graduate,

226.text:
then what? You know, I mean obviously, I know
you're gonna enroll this weekend at Liberty,

229.text:
but outside of that... hint, hint. Outside
of that, then what? Like what - what do you,

235.text:
what does your future look like, what's the
five-year game plan?

239.text:
>> ROBERTSON: Well, that's kind of a hard
question to answer because, I would have never

243.text:
guessed I would be where I am now, and so
normally when people ask me that I say, I

248.text:
try not to really plan because God's done
such a great job just taking me where he wants

254.text:
me to be, and I've loved to follow it - it's
been fun. Right now we're actually working

259.text:
on a tour, which is really exciting. So Live
Original is the book that I wrote, and we

265.text:
did a Live Original Live event at Lipscomb,
and so we're hoping to make that a tour and

270.text:
like, take it everywhere, because it was so
fun! It was really awesome. That's probably

274.text: been the- my favorite thing - event so far.

276.text:
>> NASSER: Yeah, that's incredible. Uh so
- you, let's get in there just a little bit

280.text:
further, on um, I mean deeper onto - you tried
not to plan, but then you just let the Lord,

285.text:
you trust the Lord, and then like Dancing
with the Stars calls you, right?

289.text:
>> ROBERTSON: I know right? So actually that's
kind of a crazy story, so that was a whirlwind,

296.text:
okay, so... on a Friday, so actually - take
it back - in June of last year, I had really

303.text:
wanted to be on Dancing with the Stars, and
so we went to LA and we had a meeting with

307.text:
these people. And they were like, "Okay, we'll
get back to you in two weeks, and you'll know

311.text:
if you're on the show." Well, two weeks went
by, heard nothing - two months went by, heard

317.text:
nothing. Then on a Friday at the end of August,
I get a call and they're like, "Hey Sadie,

322.text:
we're really sorry but we're just not going
to have you be on the show this year. Um,

326.text:
maybe some other time." And I'm like okay,
that's cool. And so, I just kind of was like,

331.text:
a little bummed, but I was like, whatever.
So then on Sunday, they called back and they

337.text:
say, "Okay, just kidding! We want to have
you on the show, but you have to fly out to

342.text:
LA tomorrow, and it all starts tomorrow. So
you have to move for three months." Starting

347.text:
tomorrow, and I'm like, no. And I literally
said no! I was like no, you know what I've

353.text:
already just accepted the fact that I'm not
gonna do it, it's fine, I'll do it some other

357.text:
season if ya'll would like me to, um, but
it was because I was so scared. And I was

363.text:
like, so fearful, and I was like, there's
no way I'm gonna move to LA tomorrow, leave

367.text:
everything that I'm doing now, and then the
next day my little sister; my mom actually

373.text:
called them back and said just give her one
more day, ‘cause she's not in her right

377.text:
mind. Just let her think about it. And so
- and I was like, "Mom, seriously, I'm not

382.text:
doing it!" So the next day, I went out to
lunch with my little sister, and she looked

385.text:
at me and she said, "Sadie can I ask you something?"
And I said, "Yes?" She's eleven. She goes,

392.text:
"Um, is this the fear talking, or is this
Sadie talking?" And I said, "Okay, okay this

400.text:
just got real" And then, I realized something
- I was like, yeah you know what? This is

405.text:
the fear talking! And it took me back to a
verse that I read in 8th grade whenever I

410.text:
was getting a little bullied and going through
some insecurities. And it says, "So then do

414.text:
not forget the confident trust that you have
in the Lord, for it will be richly rewarded."

418.text:
And I was like, you know what, God could have
so much planned in this. And it's not about

424.text:
being confident in myself, it's about being
confident in what God can do through me. And

429.text:
so, I mean, obviously I said yes! I did it!
And it ended up being such an awesome thing.

436.text:
>> NASSER: Yeah - I actually - I actually
think it's in a - you have a lot of fans.

441.text:
But um, I actually think it's, yeah - they
love you. You know these people pack heat

450.text:
right? You know these are some NRA, rifle
owning people. And there will be some daddy

458.text:
with some shotgun saying, “back up.” Um,
what I really appreciate though is that you

465.text:
understood the gravity of it, and I think
sometimes the tension of it is, that maybe

470.text:
there is fear, but it's really like, "Man
I don't want to fail God, I don't want to

474.text:
- I actually think that even inside of that,
and where God is like, stretching you and

480.text:
allowing you to grow in faith, and to say,
I can't, but he can through me. I actually

484.text:
think there's a maturity in that story because
you're saying, it wasn't like yeah, I'll just

491.text:
crush this right off the bat. And I think
that just shows that God's given you a lot

495.text:
of gifts, but a lot of times we elevate people
on gifting, instead of really elevating them

500.text:
on not just the gifts of the spirit, but the
fruit of the spirit as well. And it just shows

505.text:
that the fact that you slowed down, you paused.
There's great wisdom in the council of many.

511.text:
You're parents spoke into it - your little
sister kind of became big sister a little

515.text:
bit. Just shows that you just - you really
were used, um, I mean God really used you

520.text:
in that sense, and then you go in confidence
when you go, and you did crush it by the way

524.text: - it was awesome, what you did.

526.text:
Um tell us a little bit more about this movement,
this- this new campaign that just started.

531.text:
I just really love it-I mean I have a daughter,
and she was telling me a little bit last night

536.text:
about Live Original, and um, just proud of
you for that. But would love to hear a little

540.text:
bit more about the thoughts behind this new
campaign.

543.text:
>> ROBERTSON: Yeah, OK. So, Live Original
- the meaning behind it, it's just being confident

547.text:
in the person that you were created to be,
and being who you are to benefit the world,

551.text:
not who anybody else is. Which we get really
confused on these days, because I did a YouTube

557.text:
video a while back and it was about comparing
ourselves to other people and the goals that

563.text:
we have. Because we look at people and we
say, "Oh, you are gold, Girl! Like if I just

569.text:
had your eyebrows and your legs then I would
just be it," you know? And like - that's - that's

574.text:
not really the case, because if you look at
human goals, you're never gonna get to that

579.text:
point. Because there's always gonna be someone
out there better than you, or prettier than

583.text:
you, or skinnier than you in a human, you
know, view.

587.text:
And so Live Original is just being comfortable
in your skin. Um - through Live Original,

592.text:
I've been doing like research and looking
into stuff, and I found out that statistics

598.text:
say that the average 16-25-year-old spends
on average five hours a week looking at Instagram,

603.text:
Twitter, Facebook, Snapchat. And 17 million
selfies are posted a day on Snapchat - 500

611.text:
million stories are viewed per day, and so
I thought about that and I thought, every

616.text:
single day we are filling our brains and comparing
ourselves to other people from how many likes

622.text:
and comments we get, to what our face is and
our body shapes look like and if we are doing

627.text:
that to ourselves, then yeah, we are gonna
get a little insecure. We are going to think,

631.text:
"Well, she's just - she has more likes than
me so she's better." You know, when that's

635.text:
not the case at all. And the problem is, one
of our biggest problems nowadays is comparing

641.text:
ourselves - is feeling insecure. And we look
up to God and we say things like, "God, if

647.text:
I just lost 10 pounds then I promise I won't
be insecure anymore." And he says, "But I

653.text:
made you altogether beautiful, my darling.
And there's no flaw in you, and I told you

658.text:
that!" And he says, "My son died for your
security, so why are you insecure?" And then

663.text:
you say, "God, it's just hard, you know? This
road is so scary." And He says, " But I conquered

669.text:
all fears." And we keep coming up with all
of these excuses. And the thing is, what I

678.text:
realized... if now is not enough for me, it
will never be enough. Because it's my problem

685.text:
- it's not God's problem. You can't do anything
and say, God - I- I mean you made me like

692.text:
this, let me just - no! It's our problem.
He made you perfect in the way He wants you

697.text:
to benefit this world. So living original
is just accepting that, and saying, "You know

701.text:
what? This is how you made me, and I'm gonna
rock it. And I'm gonna go out here, and I'm

704.text:
gonna use it to benefit you. And so that's
the movement - that's what it's all about

709.text:
and we are um, we've done little skits, we've
connected with other people in the world who

715.text:
are living original like Sean and Catherine
Lowe. I think Sean actually spoke here, which

720.text:
is awesome! Um, we love them. And then For
King and Country sang, and so that's the movement

725.text:
we're trying to start and go on tour with
that, so yeah! It's been fun.

728.text:
>> NASSER: That's amazing - so proud of you.
That's great. I think, the spirit of comparison

734.text:
is never good - I just don't know one moment
in your life where you would look at comparison

740.text:
and see that as a godly spirit. It's always
a divisive spirit. It’s always - comparison

746.text:
is either gonna make you feel superior, because
you compare yourself and go, "I'm better than

750.text:
that person." Or it makes you feel inferior.
You either see this um, this real insecurity

756.text:
in comparison where you just go, why can't
I have that? Why's that person always - like

760.text:
they don't, they don't have any financial
trouble - they have all these friends, and

764.text:
dealing with loneliness, and this person's
always surrounded with a little tribe of people

768.text:
around them. So you either, you know end up
looking up to people, and you're not content

773.text:
with how God made you wonderful, and fearful,
it- and created you very unique and original

778.text:
or, you look down on people and go why can't
they be more like me? And so it's never the

783.text:
nature of - it's never the Spirit of God.
And so it's very valuable what you're doing,

789.text:
and that message isn't just for young ladies
- I think men struggle in a different way

793.text:
with insecurity, uh you know, I don't think,
"God, I wish I was skinny like that guy,"

798.text:
I just think, "Man, I wish I had influence.
Men are always providers. Like, I wish I had

802.text:
more money to provide for my family, I'd have
a bigger house to put my family in," or, or

806.text:
whatever. But it's the same thing so, just
incredible that God's doing that in your life!

812.text:
We need to really be praying for you in this
new season, cause it's a much needed thing,

817.text:
what you're doing in this movement. So we
want- we want to bring your mom up now, and

821.text:
so can we just put our hands together for
Kori Roberston everybody? Come on have a seat

834.text:
>> KORI ROBERTSON: Hey thanks for having me!
I'm excited to be here. You know when Duck

838.text:
Dynasty first started, I was - I got this
all the time, it's like, "Are you the wife

843.text:
of that guy with the big beard that's like
the boss of the TV show?" And I was like,

848.text:
"Yes." And then when Sadie went on dancing
with the stars, and I got, "Are you Sadie's

850.text:
mom?" I was like, "Yes." So I'm not - I'm
not bad about that.

855.text:
>> NASSER: Well you're a cool mom, it's just
– just, let's just call it like you're,

862.text:
you're like a celebrity mom, a fun mom. But
uh...

866.text:
>> SADIE ROBERTSON: She's embracing the mom
status, ‘cause she's like, "Do I look too

869.text:
much like a mom in this outfit?" I was like,
you are a mom, girl. Own it!

875.text:
>> NASSER: I've just got to ask, like you
share some of um, and I know you're about

882.text:
to have a book that comes out in October where
you actually are, but, it's not actually out

885.text:
yet so can you just share some of the principles
and characteristics which you raised up your

891.text:
kids? Because, honestly, just being around
your family has been very impressive. You

897.text:
know, your son is actually one of the student
workers in one of my departments, and I have

902.text:
watched them not come into this school, and
want to be a celebrity. I've watched he and

905.text:
his wife, um, you know Mary Kate just come
in, and he literally looked at me and said,

911.text:
"Pastor David, I'll wash dishes, I'll sweep
- I've come to serve." And he's been that

915.text:
way; he's been a real servant. Uh, Mary Kate
told me yesterday, she goes, "I'm learning

918.text:
how to do the little coffee machine back there."
You know? And so they're not looking to hobnob

923.text:
the greenroom, they're looking to come and,
and serve and it's just impressive, right?

930.text:
I don't even know what happened. Anyway, so
- just can you- can you let us know like,

938.text:
and then we see your daughter and the way
that she's just handling this opportunity

942.text:
that God has given her with humility. Give
us some of those, and I know, strong and kindness

948.text:
is coming out, but since it's not out yet,
tell us some of the principles that just drive

953.text:
>> KORI ROBERTSON: Well, yeah, the book is
about parenting, and I know a lot of you aren't

958.text:
parents yet, but it won't be long. Now that
I have John Luke and Mary Kate are married,

961.text:
I'm looking forward to grandkids. Hint, hint!
No pressure!

965.text: >> NASSER: They're going to them on the camera.

970.text:
>> KORI ROBERTSON: They're turning bright
red right now.

972.text:
>> NASSER: By the way that is not a kiss-
cam. That is not

984.text:
>> KORI ROBERTSON: Poor Mary Kate, we brought
her into this crazy family and it's like,

987.text:
it's a crazy ride. But no so it won't be long
and when you become new parents, it is - it's

995.text:
just like you feel like so, it's just crazy
like all these decisions to make like whether

1000.text:
to like give them a pacifier or to let them
sleep in your bed, or to like - all these

1006.text:
decisions all the sudden come upon you as
a new parent, and so, I was actually at a

1011.text:
Bible study when the kids were little, and
one of the ladies said, "What values and traits

1017.text:
do you want to instill in your children?"
And then it just hit me, I came home that

1021.text:
night and I was like, like this is not about
like, you know all the little, bitty decisions

1024.text:
you make as a mom, it's really about the big
decisions about how - what kind of values

1030.text:
and what you want your children to be when
they grow up, and how - the kind of adults

1034.text:
you want them to be and live in this world,
and that's kind of where Strong & Kind came

1038.text:
about - I wanted them to be strong because
I knew that they were gonna deal with some

1041.text:
tough times in this world - there's - it's
not easy, there are hard things that are gonna

1045.text:
happen to 'em. And I wanted to have the strength
that comes from knowing that God is with them,

1050.text:
and when He is for them, then nothing can
be against them. And I wanted them to have

1056.text:
that strength that like, even though they
might be tossed and turned, they would never

1060.text:
break, they will - they will keep their roots
in God, and um, in who, who is living in them.

1066.text:
And then I wanted them to be kind ‘cause
I wanted them to live among other people in

1071.text:
this world, and to treat everyone with goodness
and kindness and love, no matter where they

1077.text:
stood, no matter what they'd been through.
And I just feel like, if you know this world

1082.text:
was a little more kind, then we would live
in a lot better place. So those were the traits

1086.text:
that I chose for the children, I just, you
know, really prayed that over them. And Willy

1091.text:
and I talked about it and we worked to instill
that in them from a very young age, you know,

1097.text:
and our kids were preachin' on the table when
they were five years old - there's a video

1102.text:
of Sadie doing that on YouTube, but, you know
they've always been kids that honor God and

1108.text:
glorify Him, and stayed humble because they
know whose they are, and it's not about them.

1113.text:
And that's really what we tried to instill
in them, and that's kind of what the book's

1116.text:
about - it's just really be intentional about
choosing values for your children, and instilling

1122.text:
>> NASSER: That's great - I think you just
said it so clearly - being intentional about

1127.text:
choosing values for your children, and then
honestly just modeling it, right? In your

1131.text:
home and you did that long before the world
brought cameras into your home and into your

1137.text:
business and you know, just like, looking
at every facet of your family and everybody

1142.text:
becoming personalities and there's a brand
that's on Walmart shelves, right? Long before

1148.text:
that, you began to put those values into your
children, and you began to model that for

1154.text:
>> KORI ROBERTSON: Yeah that's really what
the second half of the book is about, like

1157.text:
if you want that for your children, you really
have to be it. And it's not easy, you know

1161.text:
if you say, "I want my kids to be courageous,"
but then you don't let them walk out of the

1165.text:
door without being fearful that they're going
to stub a toe, you know? You can't - unless

1169.text:
you're really living it, and I think that's
one of the most detrimental things to kids

1174.text:
- to see people who aren't real at home, who
when they go out in the world, they're like,

1179.text:
"Oh everything's great, and it's all perfect
and our world is so awesome," and then behind

1183.text:
the scenes, behind closed doors, they're not
living like that. They're not - they're not

1188.text:
being true to who they are - they're not being
confident in who they are. They're griping

1191.text:
and complaining because someone down the street
has something better than I do, or they're

1195.text:
being dishonest with their spouse, or they're
being - and so if we as parents come home

1201.text:
and we're not living it, then you know, our
kids are gonna feel like they're living a

1206.text:
lie and they're not gonna respect us and their
not gonna ultimately respect God and honor

1210.text:
Him because that's the ultimate goal, is to
not just have our kids honor and respect us,

1214.text: but to have them look to Him.

1216.text:
>> SADIE ROBERTSON: Yeah, and I think that
this is one of the funnier questions that

1220.text:
we get asked - you wouldn't think it would
be, but people will say, "So whenever you

1226.text:
went on Dancing with the Stars, or whenever
you all started Duck Dynasty, how did ya'll

1230.text:
decide like, to be so like Christian." And
I'm like, "Well, we didn't just decide whenever

1237.text:
the show started that we'd all be Christians,
you know? Like this has been our life like,

1242.text:
for a long time. And like, it's not an act.
And like, this is something that we try to

1248.text:
do all the time. Because living for God is
not something you just say, "Okay I'll do

1252.text:
it when I go here, but then when I go there?
Forget it!" No it's like a all the time things

1257.text:
that you do. It's living in you. And it can't
help but come out when it's in you.

1262.text:
>> KORI ROBERTSON: And we're certainly - we're
certainly not perfect, you know, we make mistakes

1267.text:
and um, you know we look to Him - to God for
forgiveness, and each other for forgiveness.

1272.text:
When we do that, and so - you know not to
say that we're perfect and that we do everything

1276.text:
right, but um, we certainly do try to honor
Him in all that we do.

1280.text:
>> NASSER: It's training up a child in the
way that he or she should go and then they

1284.text:
won't depart from it, and sometimes it's modeling
holiness - a personal pursuit of holiness

1290.text:
as a mom and a dad. And then sometimes it's
actually failing in front of them and watching

1294.text:
the conviction of the Holy Spirit - you watch
your mom and dad. Again, it's not perfection,

1298.text:
but it's a pursuit of God and the fruit of
that, is that you've raised up children now,

1304.text:
that are ready for the platform. So many times
we see a young person raised up, and as they

1309.text:
get raised up they have a lot of gifting,
but they don't have a lot of character. And

1313.text:
you just watch those people, you know - just
fail, miserably and the world just is broken

1318.text:
hearted to see somebody, who at a very early
